pros: Excellent benefits, including 401k matching, tuition reimbursement, student loan contributions, EAP program including mental health services.  Success sharing payouts. Great place to work to gain some experience and even attend school. If you're fortunate your department's culture may be amazing but still subjected to overarching structure.
cons: So many to list. Limited opportunities for career development or advancement. There's a heavy focus on developing clinicians - which is great - however it leaves administration and other non-clinicians neglected. Even THR's own employees and leadership agree that the best way to seek advancement is to leave, gaining experience elsewhere, to return later. This is not something to boast about. LOTS of politics which leaves driven employees with the short end of the stick. No longer conducts performance reviews, compensation increases are set at the system level. Internal certification programs are extremely and unnecessarily difficult, you're better off seeking certs outside. Knowingly grooms employees for advancement experience but denies opportunities when the time comes, claiming lack of experience or education (when education and experience are acquired). If a specified employee is in mind for a promotion, the job posting is listed for x number of days to satisfy HR requirements. Will not actually approach or consider other employees - often leaving employees unaware that the opportunity is available. Such a rush to return to the office environment without taking into consideration mental health impact or employee surveys (not just surveying senior management! Not all mgmt you survey will engage their employees in reporting their responses!), when it's been demonstrated that remote work has been successful. Super archaic processes and culture - not very innovative and late to adopt technology which is embarrassing and impacts business. Some efforts have been shown to foster supporting diversity & inclusion but many of the workforce is very prejudiced.

review_title: My hospital is changing...for the better!
pros: Competitive pay; great benefits especially the 401K match; paid time off, tuition reimbursement, flexible schedules, and benefits available for part time staff.  I have a lot of autonomy and decision making authority in my job.  Administration seems committed to positive change and we have seen remarkable increases in our patient satisfaction scores and safety scores in the past year.  Computerized charting (electronic medical record) is wonderful.  High performance expectations.  Overall professional, collegial work atmosphere.  Great to be part of a larger system.
cons: Smaller hospitals are negatively impacted when new safety programs, regulatory, or compliance requirements come up due to fewer overall support staff in education, etc.  Many managers/directors are responsible for multiple clinical departments but have all the same meeting requirements as those at larger hospitals with just one, leading to lots of time away from the hospital.  THR needs to open up the purse strings in relation to capital spending on equipment and needs to make integrating all software systems with the EMR a priority.

review_title: Be careful and keep your eyes, ears, and options open
pros: Good work life balance, salary is fairly competitive, at least when you hire in. Benefits are decent, not excellent. PTO (personal time off) is very generous. Tuition reimbursement is awesome. Some IS positions allow remote work which is a nice perk.
cons:
THR is technically a non-profit, but in practice that is in name only. They are the most profit-minded non-profit I've ever seen. CEO and executive salaries are simply ridiculous, some of the highest in all of North Texas, even including for-profit companies. 6 million for the CEO in 2009 (this is public information, not an insider secret). Ridiculous.

They say they have a culture of caring, but in reality they are quick to lay off regular employees, but not executives, as soon as there is a hiccup in the numbers. If they really cared about their employees they wouldn't have to keep telling you how much they care.

Layoffs happen about every 3 years, and it's just luck of the draw if you get cut. Unless you know somebody. With 600 IS employees, the organization is too big to remember an individual's long-term contributions and loyalty. It doesn't matter how many amazing things you've done, as soon as a new management team comes in you could be out the door. Unless you know somebody. Upper management in IS is VERY political and they tend to be loyal only to their inner circle.

review_title: Great benefits, if they don't lay you off
pros: Excellent benefits package, affordable insurance, excessive amounts of PTO
cons:
Constant hiring freeze even though every department is understaffed and stressed, including medical staff, which is an extreme safety issue. 

Trying to take shortcuts at every turn at the expense of the patients who just want adequate care. It's a lawsuit waiting to happen.  Budgets are cut in half, can't even find trash bags because they don't want to order supplies and then they blame the poor housekeeping staff for over using them.

Lots of layoffs recently, managers and long term employees have been fired due to department redistributions.

If someone quits, they just eliminate the position instead of replacing them, forcing everyone to do double/triple the work.

Are looking to outsource more and more and are willing to sell their employees like slaves to these new companies with no severance or chance at unemployment.

Don't let all these nice reviews fool you, the hallways are filled with nothing but panicked whispers from the staff about whose next to have their jobs eliminated. I've never seen morale so low and people who have been there for a long time are scrambling to retire before they can be laid off.

They don't call people "patients" anymore, they call them "consumers" because their only concern is money now.

It used to be worth the stress, but not anymore!! Don't work there, don't even use their services. Just do yourself a favor and head to Baylor.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Fort Worth, TX
pros: pray at meetings, large organization that tries to stay ahead of Medicare and insurance changes and help MD's make more money and run their practices more efficiently
cons: I agree with everyone's complaints about management. It is hard to find out who to go to with problems and they always seem to look out for the interest of the MD's and company, not midlevels or office staff.  They keep people for a long time that obviously do not work well with others or encourage a team environment. The NP's are not treated as professionals, and though we make a lot of money for the MD's and the company, (because we bill for our services just like an MD), they act like we are just low level employees. We don't have the same access to upper management or respect, yet we pay the same 23% to the company for "practice management" and billing fees.

pros: The insurance and wages are good.
cons: They promote a mission of integrity and respect, meanwhile "restructuring" their departments so that people who have worked there for 10, 20, or 30 years lose their jobs.  This has happened 4 times in the last year to 3 different departments and those are only the ones I know of.  They want to save money, I get that, but they are outsourcing to vendors who they apparently have not screened very well or they just do not care.  They assure you a job with the outside vendor and therefore do not have to pay severance.  The outside vendors are supposed to give you packages that are consistent with your current package but my pay was cut in half and insurance was 10 times what I was paying.  This is supposed to be a nonprofit, religion based facility, they do not promote this.

cons: Hand sanitizers are too harsh, they are without moisturizers included. Higher ratio of patients to RN compared to other facilities so high burn outs. No time for adequate patient education and empathy quality time is limited because time is a constraint for juggling so many tasks. PCT is a huge shortage so RN are doing PCT work half the time. Lunch breaks are often interrupted bc of patients needs and team members are already too busy with their own patients.

pros: Many departments, groups and individuals to work with. Time off is limited. THR Corporate is constantly growing and changing.
cons: Silos are large and tough to break through. The left hand has no idea what the right hand is doing in this corporation. Amazing behavior by certain employees and departments which becomes "status quo" for years. (i.e. Taking over a week to grant system access to RNs. Think about it..... if you are an RN who can't chart, you are an RN who can't work. And that's ok with you?) A ITS Help Desk who tries to help, but they are just another cog in the wheel. And worst of all, leaders who don't lead. Some managers have few to no people skills. Many were promoted since they knew or are related to someone.

cons: Average PTO bance, earn 6.65hrs every 2 weeks. If I didn’t have bills I’ll be gone and TRUST I’m looking.

pros: The staff are great!  I would consider the nurses I work with as my friends. The hospital is very close to my home and the ED sees patients quickly due to their 30 minute promise.
cons: Lack of accountability and follow-up.  Some managers are almost afraid to repremand nursing staff  that are not team players.  Lack of Senior Management when it comes to rounding or visiting with their staff.  Not all nursing staff is computer literate, provide more education where the IT trainers can come to the nurses instead of expecting the nurses to attend a class.  Most nurses are not compensated to attend non- nursing classes and IT classes are not considered "clinical" classes by nurses.

review_title: Use to be great, bad place to be now.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It use to be a great place to work.
cons: New management has torn the system up.  The fact that THR allows this to happen is horrid.  In my former department all older and more experienced techs are pushed out and /or fired.  The management and upper management is almost abusive.  Human resources backs up the behavior by also stressing out employees seeking help.  We are replaced with cheaper employees that have no experience yet.  They can be great one day but that is not the point.  It is almost wrong to have a license and experience.  I never knew that could be a bad thing.  At THR it is.  I do worry that in the end a patient will pay the price for unhappy employees and the horrible way management is "Doing it for patient care."

review_title: Management doesn't get the relationship between staff satisfaction and patient satisfaction
pros: Good working relationship between physicians and nurses. Lots of protocols that make taking care of the patient easier. Having enough supplies and getting what you need is not a problem. Staff throughout the building care about one another and the patients.
cons: Never enough staff. New senior management will not allow use of agency, so regular staff are overworked on a regular basis. More and more regulatory compliance paperwork is being dumped on frontline staff, taking them away from patients. Feedback is always negative. Building is old and outdated - some units have duct tape holding counters, floors, and doors together. "Shared governance" is an illusion.  Senior nursing leadership is entirely autocratic.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Dallas, TX
pros: Affordable health and dental coverage. Hospital is nice with a great charting system used.
cons: Management is horrid; nurse managers do not stay around long; some do not communicate well with employees.  As of late, employee turnover rate has been high, recently lost 2 evening nurses, 1 evening tech, 2 day nurses, and 2 day techs all within a 6 month period. THR organization has dramatically gone down hill since 2013. This company is supposedly non-profit, but keeps buying up new hospitals and business ventures. Also, every few weeks there is a "new" motto, or a "new" acronym, none of which have anything to do with patient care. The initial core value has been lost and replaced with making THR "the best place to work list in D Magazine" .

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Plano, TX
pros: Positive environment, friendly coworkers, usually easy to work with issues such as scheduling with management.
cons: Training stinks-you're being corrected a year later for a training faux pas. Management in the PAS department is passive aggressive--everything is fine until it's not and a huge hammer comes down with extreme results. Training opportunities exist only if it helps management--when additional training is requested because you don't feel like you know your job to the extent you should (due to lack of training at the beginning) it is acknowledged but no follow up exists. Management doesn't know how to reassign or fire due to lack of ability to fulfill duties. Management is always looking for tips to improve but if it costs money now to decrease costs later it is passed by.

review_title: THR believes in its services and the importance of fostering the culture to assist the frontline employee in achieve.
pros: Partnerships with several universities, including TCU and UTA to help clinical staff pursue higher degrees. THR places great weight on leadership, stewardship, diversity, compassion and respect. We celebrate successes regularly. Senior leadership stay connected through a variety of avenues. Hospital-wide, the staff are encouraged to socialize as well as develop and learn about new opportunities or process changes. This is achieved through Town Halls, frequent training, committee work, emails, staff meetings, etc. to ensure an open avenue of communication throughout.
cons: As in many hospital settings, some departments tend to remain in their own silos by the nature of their service line. The employee cafeteria food is horrible, unhealthy and pricey.

review_title: I have a Love/Hate relationship with this job...
pros: The high level management team really does want you to be happy, productive and engaged and try to touch base with each employee on an anonomous basis to see how their mid-level management team is doing.
cons: They are so politically correct, you can't breathe without offending someone.  Mid-level management is a tight circle so moving internally is difficult and if you get on the bad side of some mid-level manager's, there is no recovery from that.  You swim with sharks every day.

review_title: In process of deciding how I feel
job_title: Staff RN in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Long standing culture of treating their employees well, long history of being the best in town.
cons: New management in town causing culture to rapidly chang; trying to be the best while seeming not knowing we already are... and in an effort to be the supposed best moving in a directing of others and thus losing quality. Not sure where they are going but it feels like employees are starting to get the shaft: Although this could be just as much as a result of changing health care dynamics r/t affordable care act, so its hard to tell where it will all land, and if its related to new management or the new political reality of health care and just trying to survive as a hospital.

review_title: Laid off after a multi-million dollar ad and name change campaign.
job_title: Health Information Specialist in Plano, TX
pros: For the most part, working at the specific hospital of TH Plano was ok.  The education assistance was pretty awesome, even for those not going into nursing or other medical fields.  They tried to come up with interesting ways to say they appreciated employees.  Employee day at Six Flags, things like that.
cons: Benefits could have been better, especially considering it was a healthcare institution, not much room to move up if you weren't in a medical field.  It often felt like the non-medical personnel were not as important or "worthy" as the medical personnel, though if it weren't for us, the hospital wouldn't run.

review_title: Best in politics without working for the government
pros: THR is a financially stable company with excellent benefits, competitive pay and opportunities for career growth.
cons: The politics in the company from top to bottom is thicker than the election with the hanging chad!  If you're in the "club" then it will work out very well for you.  If you're not, then you'll want to fly below the radar with the other 90% of the people.

review_title: Wonderful place to work where they listen to you if you speak to the right people.
job_title: Admissions Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: They pay well and have cheap but very good benefits! HR is very helpful and listen to you even over the most tiniest issues.
cons: The clinical staff worked a lot better together than the clerical staff did. Additudes run higher among the clearical staff.

review_title: A decent place to work as long as you stay out of sight of upper management.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Fort Worth, TX
pros: They have a good reputation in the area.  They keep compensation competitive.  I have never felt the need to ask for a raise as they do market surveys and raise pay to remain competitive.  They are private not for profit which tends to allow higher quality equipment and facilities for the patients instead of trimming every penny for upper management bonuses.
cons:
The worst I can say is they don't try to be exceptional.  Though at least one of their hospitals has the "magnet" designation, any floor nurse will tell you this has little to no effect on actual care given to patients.  
The health insurance plan is the poorest I have seen for a hospital system.

review_title: Overall a great place to work and proud to say I worked there!
pros: Skill development, community time off (8 hours paid to do volunteer work), timely reviews, generous PTO, stable work environment, current equipment/technology.
cons: Long time employees are promoted into management when not necessarily fit for the job, raises were small (2-3 % would probably be average) and seemed to be a cap on number of "top performers" per team who would qualify for higher amounts, little turnover made it difficult to advance. Aging management at all levels.

review_title: Profit driven atmosphere. Terribly staffed and though the promise is humanitarian, their departments and politics push time restraints and financial downfalls.
job_title: Patient Transporter in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It helps my financial needs be met.
cons: Faith based yet profit driven.  The politics are absurd, the standards are not enforced, the company takes pride in the community, but refuses to treat employees with care. Very unhappy and heavily looking after almost 2 years of ridiculousness. The company has taken a huge downfall as they hire ignorant nurses, among the rest of the staff that also do not want to be there or work, so they complain loud enough for patients to hear them... seriously....

review_title: Most Terrible Experience EVER as a NICU NURSE
pros:
Flexible and great pay
Working with the various hospitals within the THR system was richly rewarding.
Kudos to THP and THD. If you want a good job as an RN in a NICU, THP and THD are YOUR ONLY OPTIONS.

Country-Club NICUs in THDN and THEB? The very worst of places to work! Terrible managers and overly 'cliquish' staff nurses and charge nurses with 'cave-man/woman' mentalities. You have to prove yourself to fit in. Like everyone wants to come in for a 'bonding experience'? *Tsk-Tsk*
cons:
The most disorganized CSO(Central Staffing Office) division I have ever encountered.
Too much drama with filling applications and the most nonsensical 'psychological profiling'.
Lack of cultural sensitivity 

If you want to work in any THR facility, avoid the CSO!

job_title: Registered Nurse in Fort Worth, TX
pros: You get to work with patients with a lot of Co-morbities. It's also a Magnet hospital.
cons: "Mean girl"  nurse cliques will SALT co-workers  for the same mistakes they themselves routinely make. Thereby using this learning tool to harass others and create unnecessary turnover.

pros: Pay, paid time off, work/life balance, 401k match, benefits, competitive compensation, opportunity for growth
cons: Great place to work if you're a medical professional.  Administrative employees are not valued as much as the hands-on patient care employees.  Upper management are a tight-knit clique that only cater to what benefits them.  Since the "ascent to summit" they've been preaching the past few years, things have gone downhill and morale has decreased.  They have brainwashed employees over the past few years that the "ascent to the summit" would result in better business practices and a better company culture, but the only result was lay-offs, and not replacing employees who leave.  This has resulted in many overworked and tired workers.

pros: Hospital staff is quite friendly (though it seems we share the misery). A very big team environment. Great benefits. Family first mentality.
cons: Administrative and admission staff are absolutely overworked with high expectations to meet and we are incredibly UNDER STAFFED and under paid! I most often do my own job as well as a handful of other people's jobs. Management are mostly ineffective (mine in particular is on vacation or on PTO than in the office working) as far as facilitating an environment for us to succeed in. The way this is going, they are going to have a hard time maintaining the current talent that they have.

job_title: ER Admissions Representative in Bedford, TX
pros: Great benefits. They give the best care to patients.
cons: When it comes to fairness you might as well forget about it. Several people are constantly calling in. You often see them on Facebook,  having a goodtime. Our manager is aware, but nothing is done about it. Also, it is the same people calling in. Favoritism is noticeable. Some employees are allowed to take a hour lunch & barely registers patients. The manager does not support or trust the team leads. The manager thinks she is being funny when she saids she thinks she ghetto or Black. Not sure what that means, but it is inappropriate. I am so glad I have resigned. I do not believe THR allows this behavior & unfairness.

review_title: Great place to learn if you have a good manager and in the right department
pros: There is opportunity to learn. flexible time for some positions. They have great investment in technology. I enjoy working with most of the people I work with. This job is within close commute from my house.
cons: Career path is not so clear or well defined. One could be in one positions indefinitely. Posting across department is not always based on merit but who you know. This is just my personal experience and does not mean this is done company-wide.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
- Management is Accessible and responsive
- Pay is fair with opportunities to earn more with the Nursing Career Advancement Program
- Good morale and teamwork
- We are recognized for our accomplishments
- Encourages further education with reimbursement programs
- Hands down, best job I've ever had!
cons:
I wish that Central Staffing was more equipped to respond to emergency staffing needs. 

Outsourcing environmental services often means that we do not have quick accessibility to trash bags and clean up supplies when needed and also, they do not clean up bodily fluids. It makes it difficult when they can't clean it and we don't have the equipment to do so.

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Plano, TX
pros: Great area to work.  Close by all the things you need to live and be happy.
cons: Administration like anywhere else needs to be revamped.  Get rid of them all and bring in fresh people to "run" the hospital.  I worked in the Surgery department and from the outside of the double doors everything looks fresh and newly updated...until you walk thru those doors.  It is a Magnet facility without the magnet feel and approach.  I agree nurses are important to any hospital but there are other professional people there that we can't do without either.  This facility needs to recognize this and acknowledge this.  If you're not a R.N.  you are nothing.

review_title: A company that lives it's Mission, Vision, Values
pros: I was so impressed with how the employees all worked together as a team.  The patient always came first...and everyone went out of their way to make sure it was a good experience.  I loved working for THAM.  I've been a stay at home mom with my kids for the last 4 years, and I have stayed connected with so many of the fabulous employees at AMH.  They really do hire the best.
cons: The parking was always a challenge...especially if you worked on the North side of the building.

pros: time off was good, insurance was good, pay was fair and met alot of nice people that weren't part of management
cons: The department I was in, the new director decreased the amount of people on 2nd and 3rd shifts, he explained his reasoning, that from all of his experience you didn't need that many people. His explanation was not entirely accurate, he did it to keep payroll down so he would get his bonus. But that was not the reason for it that he told us. he didn't care about how is crew was doing, he wasn't looking out for us, is motivation was persoanl gain. That was just a sample of his managing style.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Dallas, TX
pros: THR must train their managers very well and give them a lot of resources, because I have not met a manager here that I didn't like. They have been more than fair to me and make every effort to give me opportunities there. I also have felt very valued as a team member there, which is very hard to find in such a large hospital.
cons: Cafeteria could be tuned-up for employees. I don't have a lot of information on benefits as I did not accept any.

review_title: Super supportive Management, flexible scheduling, good 401 contribution match, tuition reimbursement, reasonable insuran
pros: My salary maxed out a few years ago so every year I get a bonus for my raise. There are lots of opportunities to be a part of and lead committees. Great people to work with.
cons: Still has 12 hour shifts... I'm getting too old for that. No place to sit and work. Must stand 90% of the time. Computers on  the walls in the halls, and only a few very high stools.

pros: I have worked for this company for almost 15 years. I started as a CNA, and they paid for my nursing school. The pay and benefits are great. There is plenty of opportunity to learn. I love this company.
cons: I wish this company was in more than just Texas in case I ever wanted to move to be closer to family. Otherwise, it is a great place to work.

pros: I’ve increased in wage each year and feel that my compensation is more than fair for the job that I do. Management is encouraging and fair and I feel supported. Our team is overall very positive. Our organization is dynamic and we are always learning and changing for the better. We have updated equipment and are always bringing in new and innovative technology such as Ivea IV poles/walkers and Sonogram for IV placement. I feel grateful, blessed and proud to work here!
cons: I can’t think of any cons. Med-Surg nursing has its bad days, but overall, I love it! Good place to work with good management.

review_title: Don't Be Fooled By These "Good" Reviews
pros: Payroll Deduction in Cafeteria, Gift shop, Jewerly Sales, Benefits, and PTO
cons: LAZY Nurses, Unprofessional Management, Racist/Entitled Co-workers, Unconcerned Human Resources Dept/Corporate, and Rude Patients

review_title: Find reasons to get rid of older employees
pros:
Things all good until employees hit 55 and older. Then all of the sudden you can’t do anything right. There are patient complaints that are made up and charge nurses not backing you as before. They seem to have an agenda for the older nurses to get rid of them as they make more $ and can hire new young nurses for half what the older nurses are paid. Though nobody will admit to this. I gave them 20 years and saw many older nurses fired or given option to resign.
Wish I had known what this company was about before giving them the best years of my career. Watch out if you’re still there and getting close to 55!
cons: They find ways to get rid of the older nurses before they can retire

review_title: I have been here for ten years.  However, I think I could do better.
pros: They are hiring, and we always need more people.
cons: Senior management cares more about the numbers than patient care.

review_title: Absolutely the best place I have ever worked. (Buyer)
pros:
First and foremost is you get to share your faith openly. 
No egos anywhere. From housekeeping to President, everyone is treated equal. I’ve seen doctors helping food services and nurses helping housekeeping. Incredible. 
Pay is on par with private sector. 
Managers, supervisors, directors keep you up to date on training and truly make the day enjoyable.
cons: PTO. Vacation and sick days all come from one bank. If you plan a vacation in advance and pay for it in advance, don’t  get sick. You may not have enough PTO to cover it.

review_title: Working in IT department is good
pros: Pay is good for the industry. Have randomly received mid-year raises to match the market. Good healthcare for what it is. Less than $100/mo for an individual. IT allows work from home. How often depending on manager.
cons: All PTO is wrapped into one basket, and there are no free days off. Need to use PTO for holidays. In IT though you can choose to work holidays though.

review_title: I really liked how we worked like a team. All for one and one for all!!🤗
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Athens, TX
pros: The feeling that you have made a difference in a life. That your work ethic and caring about doing a good job is sometimes noticed. Working a a team is great.
cons: Not enough close employee parking. Employees calling in sick a lot . Not enough employee perks. More 401k company contribution would be nice and more vacation time for tenured employees.

review_title: Don't look for your future here...
pros:
Co-workers are generally good people 
There are alot of THR locations around DFW
The potential to be a great place to work here does exist
cons:
Knee-jerk reactionary management 
Inmates are running the assylum 
Disconnection from the front lines to the C-suites
You become expendable as soon as management makes their next budgetary mistake

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: They always find coverage for your days off if you are the first or second person to request time off.  It helps make it easy for people to get the time off they want. They should really hire more PRNs to help cover PTO requests. Also, tuition reimbursement is pretty awesome.
cons: Like most healthcare organizations, there is constant reorganization to keep up with new standards and budgets. They are reluctant to replace employees after they leave and the managers constantly have to justify FTEs.

pros: Depending on the department, you can find some really good groups of people with which to work. The lower levels of management that I came to know, really knew how to promote teamwork and weren't afraid to work with you.
cons: Some of the higher levels of management have the need for refresher courses in some aspects of mangement, such as real conflict resolution or how to lead by example.

review_title: Benefits are the only good thing
pros: Great benefits and that's about all
cons: Lots of bullying happens here.  HR stirs the pot and rules by fear.  THOP to be specific.  Lots of turn over because they won't hire experienced people without degrees for Director positions.  This means no upward movement, unless you were grandfathered in,  so why stay?

review_title: Frustrating, constant management turnover, clueless initiatives and no promotion from within opportunities.
pros: Of the nearly 20,000 employees there are a large number who are outstanding.  Unfortunately most leave.
cons: HR is an absolute joke.  The company has changes 180 degrees in the last 5 years.  Nothing but slogans designed for marketing, including 70 million dollars spent on a "Branding Campaign" that resulted in the same name! Of course the employees are given a 20 dollar xmas bonus in the form of a walmart card!

pros: The benefits are okay.  Nothing over the top, but better than some companies offer.  They offer competitive compensation at least as far as starting salaries are concerned.
cons: The company culture is reminiscent of companies from over 50 years ago.  They practice a top down managment style.  Very little collaboration and development exists for lower level employees.  This is an extremely elitist organization.  If you're looking to start low and get development for advancement, this is not the place you want to be.

pros: Worked at Texas Health Cleburne for 10 years. Was a great place to work for 9 years. Great people to work with.
cons: When new management came in the hospital began a steady decline,  morally and financially.  In September I was,asked to terminate 5 employees for budget purposes. No valid justication given other than "they" wanted to go a different direction.  The new administration was/is a heavy handed micromanaging group.

pros: Culture, living and focusing on Mission / Vision / Values. The wide variety of opportunities that THR is trying to impact the health of the community around us.
cons: Growth opportunities for leadership positions outside of non-clinical & away from corporate, Admin Fellowship gets advancement over experienced dedicated employees. Focusing to much on reducing cost and not focusing on waste to improve quality that will reduce cost.

pros: They pay much better then its competition. Their EHR is Epic which in my opinion is  better then what I've seen.
cons: There is constant negativity on the employee. Lots of criticizing instead of encouragement.  Constant threats of suspension over minute task such as completing a company module. Excessive in hiring middle management but overworked bedside nurses. Safe patient-to-nurse ratio not honored.

pros: Competitive pay, profit-sharing bonuses received annually, company is constantly striving to improve. Friendly personnel. Starbucks on site. Tuition assistance.
cons: Not an active CNO, poor training, lack of lift equipment on unit (have to share with other units which is impractical), tiny cafeteria with limited options, none of which are very good. Unit management was very biased and played favorites. Lack of consistency in hospital protocols.

review_title: Use THR to get experience in IT then leave to further your career
pros:
There are some really wonderful people at the hospitals!  I've made a lot of friends and love them like family.
Benefits are typical to what you will find anywhere else.
You can get hired into entry-level positions quickly and then gain experience to try and work your way into a decent position within a few years.
cons:
Company is a HUGE healthcare conglomerate now, so it moves VERY slowly and is plagued with bureaucracy at every level - even with small requests like simply requesting the equipment to do your job.  You will constantly feel as though leadership and security NEVER trust you with even the smallest tasks.
Pay is lower than average for entry-level IT despite what their HR often (inaccurately) claims.
Also, like all bureaucracies, the leadership is out of touch with the common worker thus they often make decisions and policies that either do not help employees, or worse, hinder their own development.
On average, there are layoffs every 2 years – mostly affecting the common workers.
Like most large companies, they use H1-B employees in IT because on the one hand they complain that they can’t find talented U.S. employees yet on the other hand won’t bother to help employees pay for IT training.  For this reason, you should not stay at this company for longer than 3-4 years or you will stagnate.  Why be loyal to an IT department that is not loyal to your development?

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Arlington, TX
pros: Good pay, easy schedule, lots of work events to participate in, all types of culture are welcomed here.
cons: Insanely stupid quotas. If you miss the quota by a dollar, they will write you up. Very strict time management.  30 min lunch, lucky to get any other breaks.. management is always breathing down your neck. You can participate in on site events, but they won't give you time back for it... I wasn't aware I would be in a call center until I was hired on, I wanted to be in a people environment.. time was so strict I couldn't even enroll in the 401k benefits.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The pay is good. They are strict but it makes for a good company to work for. They pay for certifications with bonus pay.
cons: Sometimes staffing can be too low.  Some days we are very short handed. I have asked for help and the manager just replys we are already overbudget.

pros: The organization's employees have tremendous heart and care for their patients.  The benefits are some of the industries best and so is the work-life balance options.
cons: There is a general lack of leadership & management training.  Managers are not always given the appropriate tools necessary to truly succeed in their jobs.  The management hierarchy is very vertical and seemingly endless.

review_title: They treat contractors fairly but with no intention to bring them on full time
pros: If you don't have any experience working on the physical layer 1 and layer 2 aspects of networks the experience is decent.  You will learn how to rack switches, upgrade IOSs, place configs on switches and you get to work with some of the latest and greatest Cisco gear.  Very physical labor makes you feel like you've really put in a good days work.  Some employees take the time to mentor you on some issues but others do not.  Given a lot of independence to perform work at your own pace.  I felt was treated fairly and people were flexible when I made mistakes.
cons: Its all layer 1.  Unless you want to remain a lower tier network technician not the place to work.  Even for the regular employees 90% of what they do on a daily basis is layer one problems and troubleshooting.  I served as a janitor to a lot of telecom closets.  About 66% of what I did was vacuuming, dusting, sweeping, and cable management.  I didn't learn very much about their network or how networks work in general.  Compensation is not great too, they come in well below other places

review_title: Patient Care Technician at Harris HEB
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Bedford, TX
pros: Management listens to questions and concerns, and really values every employee's input. I truly feel like part of a family at THHEB, and I know my management team cares for me as an individual. Also, the tuition reimbursement program rocks!
cons: We are consistently understaffed at Springwood Behavioral Health Hospital and I am often pulled in many different directions during one shift. Most days I feel like I can't give 100% to two different jobs at one time.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The pay is mediocre at best. I should be making at least $5 more, and have been offered such, however the insurance is incomparable.
cons: The staff is very ill-trained. Very poor communication throughout the facility, "agendas" pushing "promise behaviors" when even the directors of the department see questions and constructive criticism as negative impulses - despite how accurate and evidence based the claims are.

job_title: Radiology Tech Aide in Plano, TX
pros: They truly care for their employees as much as their patients. Frequent employee appreciation lunches and perks, in addition to a generous benefits package that is unique for today's work environment.
cons: Promotion opportunities are slow since tenure is high and turnover is low there. You will have to also be trained for clinical care even if you aren't in a clinical role.

review_title: Not by my choice but, my blessings for this season in my life came to an end!
job_title: Human Resources in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Good benefits. I love being able to work more than one job at multiple entities around DFW; ex: 2 part-time positions at 2 different hospital entities or a part-time and a full-time at 2 different hospitals.
cons: Some of the recruiters at the different hospitals entities really don't have your best interest at heart.  If they have a personal unpopular issue with you; you don't have a professional chance at that entity at all.

review_title: Decent benefits, but poor raises and benefits favor some over others.
job_title: Private Pay Collector in Arlington, TX
pros: Health Benefits with the exception of weight loss surgery. I am being forced to spent $5000 out of my pocket while a smoker or drug user gets free help. Otherwise, I do like that I have the freedom to do my job, and I like the Paid Time Off, which I can use whenever I need it. I also like the 401K match, it is excellent.
cons:
Too big and they want you to be a clone. I tried to ask for extra work during a downtime and there is nothing I could do. 
I looked at my pay raises for the last four years and my increases have been $.40 cents an hour at most. I do make bonus which is 2% of my collections. It makes me feel like I am not valued as an employee with raises like that. I am a good collector and make excellent bonus, but the hourly pay says how much they value you and I guess they don't.

review_title: Good place, good salary, too religious
job_title: Health Information Management Specialist in Arlington, TX
pros: Great culture, people seem to really like each other. They pay was also pretty good.
cons: Way too religious, if you are not comfortable with religion being at the forefront of your day dont apply. Micromanage-y, no shift flexability.

review_title: Not better or worse than other hospitals
pros: Really good tuition reimbursement compared to other hospitals in the area. Really decent care provided to patients despite the Ebola incident - the nurses really do care. some IT departments are allowed to work remotely.
cons: Health Benefits are so so - have been getting more expensive year by year. Promotions are hard to come by unless you 'know somebody'. Layoffs coming up this Nov 2015. PTO bucket covers both sick pay and vacation time, so you really need to be careful with your hours.

review_title: I enjoy working for this company
pros: Texas Health Resources promotes education to it's employees. It's a company I enjoy working for.  My Director is fair person to work for. I respect him greatly.
cons: You will have cons every place you seek employment.

job_title: Staff RN in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Loved working at this awesome hospital. Husband's job moved us away. $10 per hour weekend shift different for nights and $6 for weekend days. On days $4 per hour starting at 1430. Profit sharing 2× year. Lots of supplies and resources available. Awesome people to work with. Great benefits and tuition reimbursement. I can't say enough about this hospital. Very clean. Magnet hospital. Lots of parking.
cons: Just really sad I had to move. Cafeteria food expensive. Subway in hospital is a plus. Nothing negative to add.

review_title: It's true, THR is one of the best places to work in DFW!
pros: Plethora of Internal Opportunities ; Compensation ; Benefits; Community Involvement; Senior Leadership
cons: Political nature can impede advancement; not enough telecommute options; CEO is visible, approachable, and involved in daily operations.

pros: There are no department pro. Company benefits are good though.
